subject: reactive
title: Brokered Communication From Service to Service
description:
Hi team, this is really great work and can't thank you enough for sharing this. It's not trivial to wrap one's head around the depth of the complexity in this code, and I've spent a lot of time doing so, but I feel like I may be missing something at this point.

In addition to the obvious client<-->backend flow whether over RPC or PubSub via WAMP, a use case that I was thinking of that would come in very handy for my own adaptation/extension of this is a more nuanced service to service communication. To be clear, as architected here, it is easy for, say, the trading execution service to listen a known-ahead-of-time topic "prices" on the broker, so that it is essentially capturing ALL of the price data that flows from the pricing service (if available, or basically just nothing if no pricing service instance is running)

However, modifying this so that the trade execution service could connect to a specific traded currency price stream using the RPC (to get topic name) then pubsub method to the least 'loaded' pricing instance seems less tractable using the current code base. Certainly on the javascript client side there is a lot of work that has been poured into this - the bulk of the magic which seems to be in the serviceClient and serviceBase and other supporting classes wherein a status stream is listened to to learn the name of the pricing service, then requests are made to that specific instance. However, has any of this logic been implemented on the backend (.net) side? Perhaps I am just missing something (as I have been known to do)...but just to be clear, the basic idea is that I want a trade execution instance on the backend to be able to find the 'best' pricing instance to use and then send a request to listen to the price feed for a specific traded currency, and not just "all" prices, since clearly in the real world there are market data pricing issues and so forth and I can't just subscribe to "everything"

If I were to try and recreate the above sort of functionality on the .net side any advice ahead of time would be appreciated - certainly starting with the javascript class and porting to .net I imagine would work eventually but seems like it could end up being a non-trivial amount of work and so I wanted to pose this question here first! and thanks again!

subject: reactive
title: Establish a consistent convention and directory structure
description: The current state of the client source code lacks a consistent style and a convention for describing the overall architecture of the web UI. This issue aims to resolve some of these issues by establishing a consistent convention and folder structure.

The first issues focused mainly on the ui components, but this could expand to all files under 'src'. The goal is to move towards a more fractal design. (ie. Feature-based vs Function-based)

Links: - https://hackernoon.com/fractal-a-react-app-structure-for-infinite-scale-4dab943092af - ‎https://medium.com/styled-components/component-folder-pattern-ee42df37ec68 - ‎https://github.com/davezuko/react-redux-starter-kit/wiki/Fractal-Project-Structure

Refactored according to the hierarchical nature of the rendered component tree.

https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1KzfGClfqM41AaSB9sSx9nUEb8eJ-JBU5gi2DlweNTH4/edit

Every component has its own folder, which houses all files that pertain to the component in question. At the minimum, the folder contains an index file, a view file, and a container file (if necessary). Component files and folders are camel-cased with the folders being capitalized. Component folders have one default export, which is container or view file if a container file is not present.

Container components (or components that interact with the store) sit at the root of the UI folder. Alternatively, we could nest the folders in the same pattern of the rendered component tree.

Presentation components live as subcomponents under their respective parent component, which is ultimately a container component. Presentation components can be composable and model the component hierarchy.

Reusable components live under a root 'commons' directory.

Actions, Epics, and Reducer live in an "Operations" file that sits at the root of a container folder; following the ducks' pattern (see links below). Alternatively, we could implement the re-ducks pattern (see links below) Links: - https://github.com/erikras/ducks-modular-redux - https://github.com/alexnm/re-ducks

title: Why WAMP & Crossbar
description: Just listened to the DotNetRocks episode. I'm so curious why you choose for WAMP & Crossbar instead of other messaging platforms, like SignalR and RabbitMQ for example. Saw the wiki entry on this topic, but unfortunately it is only a placeholder. Could you enlighten us :) ?

Hey promontis,

We used SignalR for messaging in the previous incarnation of Reactive Trader with clients communicating with a single service and it worked well.

For this project, we were working with a number of services and were looking to minimize the number of connections a client had to make so decide to use a broker. This ruled out SignalR. As far as broker choices go, Crossbar.IO isn't as fully-featured as RabbitMQ but it does everything we need (RPC & pub-sub) and runs out of the box over websocket with long-polling fallback, like SignalR but with a broker.

Looking back, as we only need to connect to 5 or 6 services, I think it'd actually be fine to connect to them directly using SignalR. We could introduce some kind of discovery service that clients could use to find out which services are available (we could have more than one of these) which would allows us to remove the broker as a single point of failure.

Hope this sheds a little bit of light. James
There's a blog post in the works on this - I'll leave this issue open until we publish that post.

Thnx for the explanation @JPWatson! Really helpful!

Looking back, would you still build everything using crossbar? Or would you use SignalR?

I've also did some searching on the internet... http://tavendo.com/blog/post/is-crossbar-the-future-of-python-web-apps/ is a good post on this subject.

WAMP compares to AMQP, and e.g. Crossbar.io compares to RabbitMQ.

Still looking into why WAMP instead of AMQP. I think AMQP is a bit more popular on the web, but I don't mind using a less popular tech if it is better suited.

Could you guys - having actually used crossbar - give something like a comparison between the two? When would you use crossbar vs the likes of signalr + rabbitmq? Or perhaps WAMP vs AMQP?

Also, did you look into stateful services? It seems a real-time trading system would be really suited. For example, Akka.NET or Azure Service Fabric.

If we didn't use a broker, I think SignalR would do the job perfectly well.

AMQP has definitely been around longer. It has a lot more flexibility that we just didn't need for this project and with flexibility comes extra complexity so we went with the simpler option. For example, one of the differences is that WAMP has request response out of the box whereas you need to build it yourself with AMQP using correlation ids or some similar mechanism.

We did look briefly at Akka.NET but didn't have time in the end to fully explore it, it's quite a paradigm shift. I think if we do have time to make a Reactive Trader Cloud v2.0, we might try to do something using the Actor model.

reference data service failure - the indicator for the corresponding service goes red - nothing else changes

pricer failure - the indicator for the corresponding service goes red - all pricing tiles go to disconnected mode - prices are cleared (no price at all or just a '-')

execution service failure - the indicator for the corresponding service goes red - pricing tiles stay the same visually but on mouse over there is an indication that you can't trade

blotter - the indicator for the corresponding service goes red - in the header of the blotter indicates that the blotter is disconnected

analytics - the indicator for the corresponding service goes red - in the header of the analytics pannel indicates that the analytics are disconnected

event store - execution will become unavailable (the UI should have nothing to do, it's exactly like if execution service was down) - in the header of the blotter indicates that the blotter is disconnected - in the header of the analytics pannel indicates that the analytics are disconnected
